Award.AwardTitle: REU Site at the Shannon Point Marine Center: Field and Laboratory Studies of Coastal Marine Processes
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides renewed funding for a REU site at Western Washington University's Shannon Point Marine Center (SPMC) located in Anacortes, WA. The program will support eight student internships each summer for five years. Interns will participate in a nine-week independent research program during the summer and will receive a weekly stipend, food allowance, housing on-site, and travel to and from SPMC. Students will be recruited nationwide and will be mentored by faculty at SPMC. Undergraduate research is a prominent part of the summer program at SPMC. The REU Site program receives a significant level of institutional attention and resources, including considerable faculty and staff time, boat-time, laboratory space, and training activities that promote the research agenda. The underlying philosophy of the program at SPMC is that students can best learn the research process by working closely with individual faculty advisors in an environment that places high value on the significance of undergraduate research. Participants will be encouraged to conduct research related to the theme of living resources and processes of the local coastal environment. At the end of the nine weeks, students will complete a written report and give an oral presentation of their research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goals of the Shannon Point Marine Center REU program are 1) to introduce undergraduate students to marine science research and 2) to help them develop the skills necessary to succeed should they decide to pursue a career in this area. Over the life of the grant, 40 students (eight per year) were recruited from around the country and spent nine weeks in residence at the marine center engaging in supervised, independent research and participating in group activities that introduced them to the ocean sciences and to the instrumentation and techniques used by ocean researchers. The students worked one-on-one with faculty mentors to develop a research project, identify hypotheses, design approaches to address those hypotheses, execute experiments or sampling plans, analyze data, and present the outcomes.

As part of the REU experience, SPMC faculty and staff hosted visits to local marine environments and conducted workshops on a variety of topics including oceanographic sampling, scientific diving, flow cytometry, image analysis, scientific communication, applying to graduate school, and scientific ethics. The students also participated in weekly "lunch with faculty" events that promoted informal conversation about strategies for success in the field and the different life paths of professors and researchers. 

At the conclusion of the program, all program participants developed a manuscript describing their work and presented their results orally at a final symposium. Many of the projects were subsequently presented at the students' home institutions or at regional or national science conferences. Where possible, the students and their mentors have worked to prepare the studies for publication in the refereed science literature. Tracking of program alumni indicates that most are pursuing science careers with many currently pursuing, or planning to pursue, graduate education in the field.
